content.question: The small block shown in the figure above was released from rest at point <math alttext="O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and slid down the track such that friction was considered to be negligible. The block reached point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> with speed <math alttext="v sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Between points <math alttext="O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, what kind of work did the track do on the block, and why?

choices.label: Positive work, because the block’s kinetic energy increased.
Positive work, because a component of the gravitational force is directed along the track, making the block gain kinetic energy.
Zero work, because the average force exerted by the track on the block is zero.
Zero work, because the track does not exert a force on the block directed along the block’s direction of motion.

content.answer: Zero work, because the track does not exert a force on the block directed along the block’s direction of motion.
